fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • Our item headlined Success for the Guardian (26 April, page 2) erroneously linked the dumping of toxic waste in Ivory Coast from a vessel chartered by Trafigura with the deaths of a number of West Africans. As we have reported previously, in a confidential out-of-court settlement last year, an agreed joint statement was issued by Trafigura and lawyers representing the claimants in the Ivory Coast, which confirmed the conclusions reached by scientific experts appointed in the case. The joint statement described the consequences of the waste dumping as at worst being "low-level" illness, as opposed to deaths, miscarriages or more serious injuries. We apologise for our error. • A piece about the proposed Wear bridge – Fingers crossed for England's tallest bridge, 1 May, page 23 – mentioned that "Labour is involved in a battle to defend Sunderland South from a Tory challenge". That should have been Sunderland Central. • An article sited London "a few hundred miles south" of Rochdale, when the distance as the crow flies is about 170 miles (She only nipped out for a loaf – but left Brown in a right jam, 29 April, page 2). • A column on songs about birds referred to Olivier Messiaen's L'Alouette Lulu as a skylark. Lullula arborea is a woodlark, the skylark is Alauda arvensis. An accompanying playlist misspelled the composer as Messaien (Readers recommend, 30 April, page 4, Film & Music). The Guardian's policy is to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please give the date, page, or web link. To contact the readers' editor's office email reader@theguardian.com; write to The readers' editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU; or phone +44 (0)20 3353 4736 between 11am and 5pm UK time Monday to Friday excluding public holidays. The Guardian's editorial code incorporates the editors' code overseen by the Press Complaints Commission: see pcc.org.uk
